courseTitle: Molar Mass by Freezing Point Depression

pageData.titleName2: Molar Mass by Freezing Point Depression

pageData.text: In this lab you will determine the molar mass of an organic solute using freezing point depression data for a solvent. Given the actual value for the compound’s molar mass, the percentage error will be determined.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 15 minutes
Activity 1: Freezing Point of Pure Lauric Acid - 20 minutes
Activity 2: Freezing Point of a Lauric Acid/Benzoic Acid Mixture - 40 minutes
Data Analysis - 30 minutes
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 15 minutes
Activity 1: Freezing Point of Pure Lauric Acid - 20 minutes
Activity 2: Freezing Point of a Lauric Acid/Benzoic Acid Mixture - 40 minutes
Data Analysis - 30 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Molar Mass by Freezing Point Depression

text: Determine the freezing point of a substance.
Determine the change in freezing point between a pure solvent and a solution of that solvent.
Calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>molality</button> of the solute in solution.
Calculate the theoretical and the experimental molar mass of the solute.
Calculate the percent error of the experimental molar mass.

pageData.text: Salting the roads is a customary practice when impending wintry weather is looming. The reason this process has lingered for so long is freezing point depression. While pure water freezes at 0 °C, when mixed with salt its freezing point drops well below zero and can assist with avoiding ice on roads or walkways. Another, more delectable, example of this concept is ice cream and sugar. Water is a large component of ice cream; while not directly added, it is the main component in the milk or cream that is used. The chemistry comes when sugar is added to the mixture. Just as salt does with water on roads and walkways, sugar dissolves in the water found in milk or cream. The fact that sugar dissolves is important as this allows it to find its way in between water molecules and prevents them from making an organized, crystalline pattern that we would recognize as ice. One may think that the fat in the cream or milk would behave in much the same way, but the fat does not dissolve in water. As a result, it cannot get in the way of crystalline formation on a molecular level.

pageData.desc: Two waffle cones with scoops of ice cream held up in front of a shop window.
pageData.altText: Two waffle cones with scoops of ice cream held up in front of a shop window.

pageData.text: Adding a solute to a solvent elevates the solvent’s boiling point and reduces its freezing point. This change is proportional to the number of solute particles dissolved in the solvent. It is the number of solute particles and not the compound identity that determines the boiling point elevation and freezing point depression magnitude. Ionic compounds such as sodium chloride (NaCl) and calcium chloride (CaCl2) change the boiling point and freezing point more than molecular compounds because they dissociate into two or more individual particles when dissolved. For example, when dissolved in water one mole of NaCl dissociates into two moles of particles: one mole of Na+ ions and one mole of Cl- ions. One mole of CaCl2 will dissociate into three moles of particles: one mole of Ca2+ ions and two moles of Cl- ions. This is why calcium chloride is more effective for deicing highways than sodium chloride. It decreases the freezing point of water further, inducing melting at lower temperatures.

<button class='glossary-text'>Colligative properties</button> are properties based solely on the number of solute particles and not their identity. The colligative properties of antifreeze in water allow it to protect a car engine from extreme heat and cold. Antifreeze elevates the boiling point of a car’s cooling system water, reducing the risk that the engine will overheat. It also lowers its freezing point, reducing the risk of cracking the engine block from ice formation during the winter.

options.text: properties based on the number of solute particles and not their identity
properties based on the intermolecular forces between molecules
properties based on the number of chemical bonds between atoms in a molecule
properties based on the types of chemical bonds between atoms in a molecule
properties based on the identity of solute particles and not their number

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Colligative properties are properties based solely on the number of solute particles and not their identity.

pageData.question: Which is the best example of a colligative property?

options.text: Pasta water boils at a higher temperature with the addition of table salt.
Ice cream tastes better with the addition of table salt to the recipe.
Table sugar dissolves faster in a warm cup of tea than a cold cup of tea.
Ice cubes become cloudy when made from cold water rather than warm water.
Calcium chloride becomes a liquid at extremely high temperatures.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Adding a solute to a solvent elevates the solvent’s boiling point and reduces its freezing point. So, the addition of table salt (NaCl) to water will cause it to boil at a higher temperature than distilled water.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Colligative properties are properties based on quantity rather than identity. For example, adding a solute to a solvent elevates the solvent’s boiling point and reduces its freezing point. This change is proportional to the number of solute particles dissolved in the solvent. It is the number of solute particles and not the compound identity that determines the boiling point elevation and freezing point depression magnitude. Ionic compounds such as sodium chloride (NaCl) and calcium chloride (CaCl2) change the boiling point and freezing point more than molecular compounds because they dissociate into two or more individual particles when dissolved.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Colligative properties are properties based on quantity rather than identity. For example, adding a solute to a solvent elevates the solvent’s boiling point and reduces its freezing point. This change is proportional to the number of solute particles dissolved in the solvent. It is the number of solute particles and not the compound identity that determines the boiling point elevation and freezing point depression magnitude. Ionic compounds such as sodium chloride (NaCl) and calcium chloride (CaCl2) change the boiling point and freezing point more than molecular compounds because they dissociate into two or more individual particles when dissolved.

pageData.text: The magnitude of a solution’s boiling point elevation and freezing point depression is the product of its and the solvent’s molal boiling point elevation constant ( ) or molal freezing point depression constant ( ). Molality is the number of moles of solute per kilogram of solvent. The boiling point elevation and freezing point depression constants depend on the solvent alone.For example, water’s boiling point elevation constant (K b ) is 0.51 °C • kg/mol, and its molal freezing point depression constant (K f ) is 1.86 °C • kg/mol. This means that for every mole of solute dissolved in one kilogram of water, the boiling point will be elevated 0.51 °C and the freezing point will be lowered 1.86 °C. For molecular compounds that do not dissociate, the relationship is shown by the following two equations:(1) ΔTb = mK b(2) ΔTf = mK f

Where ΔTb is the change in boiling point between the solvent and the solution, and ΔTf is the change in freezing point between the solvent and the solution.For ionic compounds that can dissociate into two or more particles, the equations are multiplied by a factor (i), which represents the total number of ion moles that the compound dissociates into. For example, CaCl2 has an i = 3.

pageData.question: Which statement is true regarding boiling point elevation and freezing point depression constants?

options.text: They are dependent on the solvent only.
They are dependent on the solvent and the solute.
They are dependent on the number of ion moles a solute dissociates into.
They are dependent on the molality of the solution.
They are dependent on the solute only.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The boiling point elevation and freezing point depression constants depend on the solvent alone. For example, water’s boiling point elevation constant (Kb) is 0.51 °C•kg/mol, and its molal freezing point depression constant (Kf) is 1.86 °C•kg/mol.

pageData.question: Which of the following values are required to calculate the magnitude of a solution’s freezing point depression?

options.text: the number of ion moles of solute, molality of the solution, freezing point depression constant
the molality of the solution and the molar mass of the solute
the temperature of the solvent, the molality of the solution, boiling point elevation constant
molality of the solution and the number of ion moles of solute
molarity of the solution and the freezing point depression constant

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: ΔTf = i(mKf), where ΔTf is the change in freezing point between the solvent and the solution, i is the total number of ion moles the solute dissociates into, m is the molality of the solution, and Kf is the freezing point depression constant.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The magnitude of a solution’s boiling point elevation and freezing point depression is the product of its molality (m) and the solvent’s molal boiling point elevation constant (Kb) or molal freezing point depression constant (Kf). Molality is the number of moles of solute per kilogram of solvent. The boiling point elevation and freezing point depression constants depend on the solvent alone.For example, water’s boiling point elevation constant (Kb) is 0.51 °C•kg/mol, and its molal freezing point depression constant (Kf) is 1.86 °C•kg/mol. This means that for every mole of solute dissolved in one kilogram of water, the boiling point will be elevated 0.51 °C and the freezing point will be lowered 1.86 °C. For ionic compounds that can dissociate into two or more particles, such calculations are multiplied by a factor (i), which represents the total number of ion moles that the compound dissociates into. For example, CaCl2 has an i = 3.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The magnitude of a solution’s boiling point elevation and freezing point depression is the product of its molality (m) and the solvent’s molal boiling point elevation constant (Kb) or molal freezing point depression constant (Kf). Molality is the number of moles of solute per kilogram of solvent. The boiling point elevation and freezing point depression constants depend on the solvent alone.For example, water’s boiling point elevation constant (Kb) is 0.51 °C•kg/mol, and its molal freezing point depression constant (Kf) is 1.86 °C•kg/mol. This means that for every mole of solute dissolved in one kilogram of water, the boiling point will be elevated 0.51 °C and the freezing point will be lowered 1.86 °C. For ionic compounds that can dissociate into two or more particles, such calculations are multiplied by a factor (i), which represents the total number of ion moles that the compound dissociates into. For example, CaCl2 has an i = 3.

pageData.text: Because boiling point elevation and freezing point depression depend on the amount of solute added to a solvent, both properties can be used to determine the molar mass of a solute. In this lab you will depress the freezing point of a solvent by adding a given mass of non-ionizing molecular solute. Rearranging equation (2) and solving for the solute’s results in the following equation (3).(3) m = ΔTf/If the solvent mass is known, then the moles of solute can be calculated using the molality equation (4) and rearranging it to solve for moles of solute, equation (5).(4) m = moles of solute/kg of solvent(5) moles of solute = m × kg of solvent
If the solute mass is known, then the solute molar mass can be calculated using equation (6):(6) molar mass = g of solute/moles of solute

pageData.question: Which of the following equations will you use to solve for molality in this investigation?

options.text: m = ΔTf/K f
m = moles of solute/kg of solvent
m = ΔTf
m = g of solute/moles of solute
m = M/i

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In this investigation, the molality equation m = ΔTf/Kf is derived from the equation ΔTf = mKf used to calculate the magnitude of change in the freezing point of a solution.

pageData.question: Which of the following describes the ultimate purpose of depressing the freezing point of a solvent with a molecular solute in this investigation?

options.text: to determine the molar mass of the solute
to determine the molality of the solution
to determine the freezing point depression constant of the solvent
to determine the ionization factor of the solute
to determine the kilograms of solvent

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Because freezing point depression depends on the amount of solute added to a solvent, this property can be used to determine the molar mass of a solute. Depressing the freezing point of a solvent with a molecular solute will allow you to calculate the molality of the solution, which in turn will allow you to calculate the molar mass of the solute.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In this lab you will depress the freezing point of a solvent by adding a given mass of non-ionizing molecular solute. Rearranging the equation ΔTf = mKf and solving for the solute’s molality results in the equation m = ΔTf/Kf. If the solvent mass is known, then the moles of solute can be calculated using the definition of molality (moles of solvent/kg of solvent) and rearranging it to solve for moles of solute, equation. If the solute mass is known, then the solute molar mass can be calculated.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In this lab you will depress the freezing point of a solvent by adding a given mass of non-ionizing molecular solute. Rearranging the equation ΔTf = mKf and solving for the solute’s molality results in the equation m = ΔTf/Kf. If the solvent mass is known, then the moles of solute can be calculated using the definition of molality (moles of solvent/kg of solvent) and rearranging it to solve for moles of solute, equation. If the solute mass is known, then the solute molar mass can be calculated.

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. You will start by pre-heating a water bath. In Activity 1, you will melt a known mass of lauric acid in a hot water bath and record its temperature as it cools to determine its freezing point. In Activity 2, you will determine the freezing point of a mixture of lauric acid and benzoic acid. You will use this data to determine the molar mass of benzoic acid.

In Activity 2, you will determine the freezing point of a mixture of lauric acid and benzoic acid. You will use this data to determine the molar mass of benzoic acid.

pageData.text: <span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Read all of the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.

Lauric acid can cause eye irritation.
Benzoic acid can cause respiratory irritation.
Benzoic acid is corrosive and can cause serious eye damage.

Do not pour warm lauric acid or the lauric acid/benzoic acid solution down the sink. It will solidify and clog the drain. After completing all the activities, discard the test tubes and their contents in the trash. The chemicals provided are safe to discard in the trash.
During the activity, water will be heated to near boiling temperatures. Handle with care to avoid burns.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing this activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing this investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read the procedure.
Obtain all materials.
Select a clean work area.

Heat 300 mL (10 oz) of tap water to approximately 80 °C. This can be performed on a stove in a pot or saucepan or in a microwave. If microwaving, use a microwave-safe container, and heat in one-minute intervals until the desired temperature is reached.

Helpful Tips:
  • The pocket scale has a four- to five-second delay when measuring quantities less than one gram. When adding small increments to the scale, wait for the readout to stop changing prior to adding additional chemicals.
  • The scale shuts off after one minute of inactivity. Be sure to record the mass measurements within this time frame.
  • Record the exact amount of lauric and benzoic acid used in each activity. The values provided are approximate. The mass of lauric and benzoic acid that is used is not important; however, the mass must be measured precisely and recorded.
In Activity 1, you will melt a known mass of lauric acid in a hot water bath and record its temperature as it cools to determine its freezing point.

pages.pageTitle:
A
 Freezing Point of Pure Lauric Acid (16 steps)
pages.title:
A
 Freezing Point of Pure Lauric Acid (16 steps)

pageData.text: Label a weigh boat “lauric acid.” Place the boat on the scale and tare to 0.0 g by pressing the right-hand button.
Using a plastic spoon, transfer approximately 3 g of lauric acid into the weigh boat. Use this spoon only for the lauric acid. Record the exact weight in Data Table 2.
Transfer the lauric acid from the weigh boat into the test tube.

The best method for transferring a solid from a weigh boat into a test tube is to bend the opposite corners of the weigh boat making a funnel shape. Place one of the corners into the test tube and lightly tap the weigh boat to slide the chemical into the test tube. See Figure 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Photo showing a folded weighing boat pouring lauric acid into a glass test tube
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Photo showing a folded weighing boat pouring lauric acid into a glass test tube

pageData.text: Place the test tube with the lauric acid in the test tube rack.
Check the hot water to ensure it is approximately 80 °C. Carefully pour the hot water into the 250-mL plastic beaker until it is nearly full. This is your hot water bath.
Insert the thermometer into the lauric acid test tube, and place the tube in the hot water bath.
Carefully tilt the test tube so that any lauric acid powder on the walls of the tube will be melted by the hot water. Do not let any water from the bath splash into the tube.
Keeping the test tube submerged with one hand, gently stir the solid lauric acid with the thermometer to speed its melting.
Once the solid lauric acid has melted completely, remove the test tube from the warm water and continue to stir gently to keep the temperature uniform as it cools.
Save the beaker of warm water for the end of this activity.
When the temperature reaches 65 °C, start recording the temperature in Data Table 1 every 30 seconds using a timer.
When the temperature reaches 65 °C, that is considered 0.0 sec. Start the timer. This data measures the cooling curve of the lauric acid solvent.
Continue stirring and recording the temperature every 30 seconds until the temperature reading remains constant for four consecutive measurements. This is lauric acid’s freezing point.
Take a photograph of the crystallizing lauric acid.
Place the test tube back in the test tube rack.

Dip a paper towel in the warm water bath. Remove the thermometer from the test tube and wipe it down well with the wet paper towel to remove any lauric acid crystals. Do not pour the warm lauric acid down the drain of the sink. It will solidify and clog the pipe.
If necessary, wash the thermometer with hot water to remove any remaining lauric acid crystals. The thermometer must be completely clean before proceeding to the next activity.

In Activity 2, you will use a similar procedure to that of Activity 1 to determine the freezing point of a mixture of lauric acid and benzoic acid. You will then repeat the activity using a different mass of benzoic acid. Finally, you will use the data from Activities 1 and 2 to perform a series of calculations to determine the molar mass of benzoic acid.

pages.title:
A
 Freezing Point of a Lauric Acid/ Benzoic Acid Mixture (7 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Freezing Point of a Lauric Acid/ Benzoic Acid Mixture (7 steps)

pageData.text: Using the weigh boat labeled “lauric acid,” weigh 3 g of lauric acid, and place it in a new test tube (outlined in steps 1– 4 of Activity 1). Record the exact mass in Data Table 2.
Label another weigh boat “benzoic acid.”
Place the boat on the scale and tare it. Use a clean spoon and weigh 0.4 g of benzoic acid. Record the exact mass in Data Table 2.
Add the 0.4 g of benzoic acid to the 3 g of lauric acid in the test tube.
Reheat the water to approximately 80 °C

Repeat steps 5 –17 outlined in Activity 1, and record the temperature every 30 seconds until the temperature remains constant for four consecutive readings. This will be the freezing point for the “lauric acid + 0.4 g benzoic acid” solution.
Repeat Steps 1– 6 using 3.0 g lauric acid and 0.5 g benzoic acid.

pages.title: Calculations for Molar Mass of Benzoic Acid
Calculations for Molar Mass of Benzoic Acid
pages.pageTitle: Calculations for Molar Mass of Benzoic Acid

pageData.text: Use three significant figures for all the answers. Record the answers in Data Table 2.

text: Calculate and record the freezing point depression, which is the difference in freezing point (ΔTf ) between the pure lauric acid and the lauric acid with benzoic acid added.
Calculate and the record the of benzoic acid. Benzoic acid is the solute and lauric acid, the solvent. The freezing point depression constant () for lauric acid is 3.90 °C • kg/mol m = ΔTf / kf .
Calculate and record the moles of benzoic acid in the solvent. Remember to convert your mass of lauric acid to kilograms (1,000 grams per kilogram).moles of benzoic acid = m × kg of lauric acid

Calculate and record the experimental benzoic acid molar mass.
molar mass of benzoic acid = grams benzoic acid/moles of benzoic acid
Calculate and record the average experimental benzoic acid molar mass.

Calculate the percent error using the following equation, the accepted molar mass of benzoic acid is 122.12 g/mol:accepted molar mass - experimental molar mass/accepted molar mass × 100 = percent error
Dispose of the weigh boats and spoons in the trash.
Place the test tubes with their contents in the hard-sided secondary container; place the secondary container in the trash.
Do not pour the warm lauric acid and benzoic acid down the drain of the sink. It will solidify and clog the pipe.
Rinse and dry the 250-mL beaker and thermometer. Return the thermometer to its holder.
Clean and sanitize the workspace.

text: Describe your observations during the four consecutive constant temperature readings. What observations were made after these readings?

pageData.text: Calculation directions for this data table are provided below.

tableData.text: Molality of Benzoic Acid in Lauric Acid
Experimental Molar Mass of Benzoic Acid

pageData.title: Calculations for Molar Mass of Benzoic Acid
pageData.text:
Use three significant figures for all the answers. Record the answers in Data Table 2.
  1. Calculate and record the freezing point depression, which is the difference in freezing point (ΔTf ) between the pure lauric acid and the lauric acid with benzoic acid added.
  2. Calculate and the record the of benzoic acid. Benzoic acid is the solute and lauric acid, the solvent. The freezing point depression constant () for lauric acid is 3.90 °C • kg/mol m = ΔTf/kf.
  3. Calculate and record the moles of benzoic acid in the solvent. Remember to convert your mass of lauric acid to kilograms (1,000 grams per kilogram).moles of benzoic acid = m × kg of lauric acid
  4. Calculate and record the experimental benzoic acid molar mass.
    molar mass of benzoic acid = grams benzoic acid/moles of benzoic acid
  5. Calculate and record the average experimental benzoic acid molar mass.
  6. Calculate the percent error using the following equation, the accepted molar mass of benzoic acid is 122.12 g/mol:accepted molar mass - experimental molar mass/accepted molar mass × 100 = percent error

text: What are some possible sources of error in this experiment?

You may continue to access the hint as you answer the new question.You can find a complete list of the figures, tables and videos in this investigation using the Resources icon.

procedure.text: You can track completion of each step by clicking on the step number.
